Nor does it mean, on the other hand, that we can explain
anti-Americanism among the Japanese as a whole by confining
the discussion to thoso Japanese who harbor, for political
or ideological reason, a more or less clear-cut antagonism
towards America.
What, then, gives shape to anti-.Americanism in general among
the Japanese people?
In trying to answer this, let’s consider the town of Sunakawa,
within the limits of Greater Tokyo—* Recently, a sensation
was created there by a movement directed against the expansion
of an American military air base. This ill-fated town has founc
itself in a dilemma because of the expansion of flying for the
past thirty yearsi It happens to lie next to the famous
Tachikawa Air Base. Thank to this unfortunate chance, it has
had farm and building land requisitioned by the authorities on
eleven separate occasions! The process began with the
establishment of the former Japanese Arrcy*s Tachikawa flying
school in 1926, and ended for the time being in November 1954*
involving in all some 460*000 tsubo (about 375 acres) of land.
The Japanese Government paid compensation on each occasion*,
but not once was it enough to satisfy the inhabitants. They
were more than tired of requisitioning when, last April there
came like a bolt from the blue the Government’s latest edict0
This was the result of an agreement between the Japanese
and American Governments. "It has been decided,1* it said,
"to requisition an area of approximately 30,000 tsubo
(about 25 acres) in the course of an expansion of the Tachikawa
airfield aimed at facilitating the take off and landing of
American jet planes.”
Let me add that the concept of land in Japan, with its
densely packed population, is different from that prevailing
in countries such as America.
